Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp with a double-convex body, a long, slightly splayed, flat-topped nozzle with a curved tip, a circular base-ring, and a leaf-shaped lug on each side. The filling-hole is surrounded by a double moulding. The shoulder is decorated with rope decoration in relief, between the outer moulding of the filling-hole. On top of the nozzle are two raised ridges, which end in volutes. The red-brown surface is perhaps slipped. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric. Nozzle is chipped.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late 3rd to 2nd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 331, Fig. 2b, see also Mlynarczyk 1997, Type F.1, Figs. 51-2). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.027) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4848 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
